awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Exo-Core: An Architecture to Detect Malware as Computational Anomalies
awd_abstract_narration:
Applications that run on billions of mobile devices backed by enormous
datacenters hold the promise of personal, always-on healthcare; of intelligent
vehicles and homes; and thus of a healthier, more efficient society.  It is
imperative to make such applications secure by protecting their integrity and
keeping their data confidential. However, malicious programs (``malware'')
today can subvert the best software-level defenses by impersonating benign
processes on mobile devices or by attacking victim processes through the
hardware on shared datacenter servers.  Grappling with such intelligent malware
requires fundamental advances in the hardware-software organization of computer
systems.

The key observation behind the research project here is that, while seemingly
disparate, intelligent malware relies on hiding its hardware-level behaviors
from operating system-level monitors. By exposing instruction-level and
micro-architectural behaviors to software analysis, the proposed Exo-core
architecture enables a new class of malware detectors.  In addition, Exo-core
introduces programmable hardware accelerators to synthesize run-time program
traces into robust models of benign programs. The project will also
integrate research in hardware-software foundations of computer security
into a new two-semester research course for undergraduate students.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
The frontiers of cybersecurity attacks and defense have steadily moved down the computing stack. Network flows begat network firewalls; application vulnerabilities led to compiler and code-analysis defenses; and by 2015, the attackers were starting to look at micro-architecture as the unguarded perimeter through which to steal data or take oversystems. Not surprisingly, such attacks hit prime-time attention withthe discovery of "Spectre/Meltdown" category of attacks in 2018.


This project -- Exo-core -- was proposed in 2014-15 to secure the foundations of computer architecture and hardware along different phases of the NIST security framework (Identify, Protect, and Detect).


The primary idea behind Exo-core is to open up the instruction-set architecture to make security-relevant signals visible to a trusted and protected security monitor (Identify). This visibility is critical to Detect software-driven micro-architectural attacks -- indeed, we showed that a diverse category of attacks on both memory (DRAM) and speculative execution and side-channels (CPU) can be detected reliably. And the software-monitor can Respond to the attacks in real-time before damage is done.


The second idea is to provide controls in the micro-architecture so that the software security monitor can isolate or obfuscate secrets from attackers (Protect). We demonstrated a range of techniques to protect programs as diverse as databases and machine learning to post-quantum cryptography implementations.


This project not only opened up considerable follow-on work by other researchers, but has spawned two security companies, impacted existing large companies' products, and yielded prestigious awards for the graduate students and undergraduates that worked on the project.


Last Modified: 06/23/2022
Modified by: Mohit Tiwari
